title: 111_s1376
content: The International Adoption Simplification Act allows for exemptions from vaccination documentation requirements and addresses sibling adoptions under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Hague Convention on Intercountry Adoption allows for the adoption of a child from a foreign state by a US citizen or couple, with certain conditions such as proper care assurance and consent from the child's legal guardians. The conditions for intercountry adoption under the Hague Convention include termination of the legal relationship with the child, the child's emigration and adoption, incapability of natural parents to provide proper care, forming a bona fide parent-child relationship, and termination of the parent-child relationship with natural parents. The foreign state must approve the child's emigration for adoption in the United States, and the prospective adoptive parent(s) must meet pre-adoption requirements of the child's proposed residence. The child must be approved for emigration for adoption in the United States by the foreign state, and the adoptive parent(s) must meet pre-adoption requirements of the child's proposed residence. No natural parent or prior adoptive parent of the child shall have any rights under this chapter. A younger sibling of a child described in certain clauses can be adopted abroad or come to the United States for adoption by the same adoptive parent(s). A petition filed for immediate relative classification under section 201(b) is subject to the effective date of the Act. An exception applies to aliens meeting certain criteria if a petition is filed within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
